prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO (2-1) 30Dor Region A
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Mapping of Region A of 30Dor.
Region A covers the previously detected CO 2-1 as well as the edge of the PDR, where CO clumps are not prominent and where we find the highest CO-dark gas fraction (fig 1). It is a region H2 will be traced preferentially by [CI]. In this region, the incident radiation field (G0) reaches 10^4 and the density (n) is greater than 10^4 cm^{-3}.
We are observing 12CO(2-1) and 13CO(2-1) simultaneously in 2 different sidebands along with C18O(2-1) and the continuum around 233.5GHz.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We can observe simultaneoulsy 12CO(2-1), 13CO(2-1) and C18O(2-1). However, we have to choose a small spectral window (117 MHz) to be able to configure the LO1 for the simultaneous observation of 12CO and 13CO.
We apply an averaging factor of 4 to lower the data rate, and keep a resolution of ~0.15km/s since we expect the line width of the CO to be ~3km/s (cycle 0 observations, Indebetouw et al. 2013). Then the lines in this band will be spectrally resolved, allowing us to probe the number of clouds on the line of sight.
We set the continuum measurement around 233.5GHz, where no strong lines will be detected, and where the atmospheric transmission is good.
References: Indebetouw et al. 2013, ApJ, 774, 73

We ask for an angular resolution of 0.5"x0.5" (~0.1 pc). This is approximately the size of the molecular gas/PDR transition gas that we expect for a half-solar metallicity gas exposed to an intense radiation field. This is supported by high-resolution studies of the Orion bar (Shimajiri et al. 2013, van der Werf et al. 1996).
We ask to recover the angular scales up to 14". This way we will observe the extended emission around the clumps, in the entire region covered by the band 10 mosaic.
References: Shimajiri et al. 2013, ApJL, 774, 20 van der Wef et al. 1996, ApJ, 313, 633

We estimate the sensitivity based on the Cycle 0 observations (Indebetouw et al. 2013). The faintest line we want to observe in this band is C18O, which drives the time estimate. It is required because 13CO was found to be marginally thick in a few locations, especially in the dense clumps we are targetting. It will drive the time estimate From Cycle 0 data, the brightest clumps have a C18O intensity of ~25mJy/beam. We then need to reach a sensitivity of 8mJy to detect C18O in the brightest clumps with a signal to noise ratio >5. If the emission is clumpier than expected, we will get a higher S/N due to our finer spatial resolution. This sensitivity allows us to detect the 13CO even in the diffuse zones. We confirm that the lines are in a good atmospheric transition window.
To reduce the integration time without jeopardizing the experiment, we can smooth to 0.3km/s (chosen bandwidth for the sensitivity calculation) and still resolve the lines in this band (line width/ bandwidth used for sensitivity = 10).
This is a single pointing. So we will reach the required sensitivity for the inner ~9" of the primary beam. This matches the size of the region that we fully sample in Band 10.
References: Indebetouw et al. 2013, ApJ, 774, 73

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CI, CO (7-6) 30Dor Region A
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Mapping of Region A in 30Dor.
Region A covers the previously detected CO 2-1 as well as the edge of the PDR, where CO clumps are not prominent and where we find the highest CO-dark gas fraction (fig 1). It is a region H2 will be traced preferentially by [CI]. In this region, the incident radiation field reaches 10^4 and the density is greater than 10^4 cm^{-3}.
We are observing [CI] 370 microns and CO (7-6) simultaneously in in 2 different sidebands along with the continuum in the other 2 sidebands.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The expected line width is ~3km/s based on cycle 0 observations (Indebetouw et al. 2013). The CO7-6 line is 6.2 times brighter than [CI] in this region, so it will be detected at least with the same S/N of 7 for a bandwidth of 0.3km/s instead of 2km/s for the sensitivity. We can then resolve the CO7-6 line (line width/resolution ~10 for this line) in order to compare the line profile with the CO(2-1) spectrum. The comparison of the line profiles of the low-J and the high-J transitions of CO will help us to determine the sub-structure of the clouds.
However, the [CI] line is fainter, so we use spectral averaging to lower the data rate and set the spectral resolution to 0.7km/s. Thus the line is partially resolved. We will smooth the spectrum to 2km/s when necessary to reach the minimum sensitivity to detect the line in the most diffuse regions, but we can also use the full resolution spectrum in the bright clumps to probe the structure.
We set the continuum measurements around 790.5 and 795GHz, where no strong lines will be detected, and where the atmospheric transmission is good.
References: Indebetouw et al. 2013, ApJ, 774, 73

We ask for an angular resolution of 0.5"x0.5" (~0.1 pc). This is approximately the size of the molecular gas/PDR transition gas that we expect for a half-solar metallicity gas exposed to an intense radiation field. This is supported by high-resolution studies of the Orion bar (Shimajiri et al. 2013, van der Werf et al. 1996).
We choose to focus on the individual clumps, with a maximum size of 1.2pc (Idebetouw et al., 20913). This is the reason why we need to recover the spatial scales up to 5".
References: Indebetouw et al. 2013, ApJ, 774, 73 Shimajiri et al. 2013, ApJL, 774, 20 van der Werf et al. 1996, ApJ, 313, 633

We estimate the sensitivity based on the intensity measured with Herschel/SPIRE/FTS for [CI] 370 microns and CO (J=7-6). Cycle 0 line widths for this region are ~3km/s (Indebetouw et al. 2013). From this, we deduce a minimum surface brightness of 103mJy in region A for [CI] 370 for a synthesized beam of 0.5"x0.5", if emission is uniform in the FTS beam. CO 7-6 emission is higher (644mJy), so the time estimation will be driven by [CI].
Moreover, from the cycle 0 observations, we expect the ISM to be very clumpy. Based on previous observations, the filling factor in the NANTEN2 data for [CI]370 and CO 7-6 is about 1/16 (Pineda et al., 2012). The resolution of NANTEN2 (26") is lower than the SPIRE/FTS beam (38"), so this gives a minimum value to the beam filling factor in the Herschel data. Thus, the emission in the clumps is expected to be enhanced by a factor of 16. To check this result, we compare the CO (2-1) value from the RADEX fit of the CO SLEDs at 43" resolution with the cycle 0 data at 2" resolution. We find a factor of 8 enhancement. We will keep this value of 8 to be more conservative and to account for the fact that the clumps will be resolved, and estimate the peak line flux density per synthetised beam : 810mJy.
Then we have to take into account the fact that our 7 pointings are overlapping (Nyquist sampling). Thus the sensitivity in the 10pc x 10pc central region is increased by a factor of sqrt(2). For a signal to noise ratio of ~7 in the diffuse regions, we require a sensitivity of 810/7*sqrt(2) = 164mJy. We confirm that the lines are in a good atmospheric transition window.
Since we do not require to spectrally resolve the lines for our study, we can post-process the data, smoothing them to 2km/s to reduce the observation time. The expected line width according to cycle 0 observation is ~3km/s.
References: Indebetouw et al. 2013, ApJ, 774, 73 Pineda et al, 2012, A&A, 544, 84

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO (2-1) 30Dor Region B
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Mapping of Region B in 30Dor.
Region B is the peak of the [CII], [CI] and CO emission lines. In this region, G0 is 3000 and the density n~5000 cm^{-3}. We identify several clumps in this region.
We are observing 12CO(2-1) and 13CO(2-1) simultaneously in 2 different sidebands along with C18O(2-1) and the continuum around 233.5GHz.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We can observe simultaneoulsy 12CO(2-1), 13CO(2-1) and C18O(2-1). However, we have to choose a small spectral window (117 MHz) to be able to configure the LO1 for the simultaneous observation of 12CO and 13CO.
We apply an averaging factor of 4 to lower the data rate, and keep a resolution of ~0.15km/s since we expect the line width of the CO to be ~3km/s (cycle 0 observations). Then the lines in this band will be spectrally resolved, allowing us to probe the number of clouds on the line of sight.
We set the continuum measurement around 233.5GHz, where no strong lines will be detected, and where the atmospheric transmission is good.
References: Indebetouw et al. 2013, ApJ, 774, 73

We ask for an angular resolution of 0.5"x0.5" (~0.1 pc). This is approximately the size of the molecular gas/PDR transition gas that we expect for a half-solar metallicity gas exposed to an intense radiation field. This is supported by high-resolution studies of the Orion bar (Shimajiri et al. 2013, van der Werf et al. 1996).
We ask to recover the angular scales up to 14". This way we will observe the extended emission around the clumps, in the entire region covered by the band 10 mosaic.
References: Shimajiri et al. 2013, ApJL, 774, 20 van der Wef et al. 1996, ApJ, 313, 633

We estimate the sensitivity based on the Cycle 0 observations (Indebetouw et al. 2013). The faintest line we want to observe in this band is C18O, which drives the time estimate. It is required because 13CO was found to be marginally thick in a few locations, especially in the dense clumps we are targetting. From Cycle 0 data, the brightest clumps have a C18O intensity of ~25mJy/beam. We then need to reach a sensitivity of 8mJy to detect C18O in the brightest clumps with a signal to noise ratio >3. If the emission is clumpier than expected, we will get a higher S/N due to our finer spatial resolution. This sensitivity allows us to detect the 13CO even in the diffuse zones. We confirm that the lines are in a good atmospheric transition window.
To reduce the integration time without jeopardizing the experiment, we can smooth to 0.3km/s (chosen bandwidth for the sensitivity calculation) and still resolve the lines in this band (line width/ bandwidth used for sensitivity = 10).
This is a single pointing. So we will reach the required sensitivity for the inner ~9" of the primary beam. This matches the size of the region that we fully sample in Band 10.
References: Indebetouw et al. 2013, ApJ, 774, 73

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CI, CO (7-6) 30Dor Region B
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Mapping of Region B of 30Dor.
Region B is the peak of the [CII], [CI] and CO emission lines. In this region, G0 is 3000 and the density n~5000 cm^{-3}. We identify several clumps in this region.
We are observing [CI] 370 microns and CO (7-6) simultaneously in in 2 different sidebands along with the continuum in the other 2 sidebands.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The expected line width is ~3km/s based on cycle 0 observations (Indebetouw et al. 2013). The CO7-6 line is 5.6 times brighter than [CI] in this region, so it will be detected with a S/N of 6 for a bandwidth of 0.3km/s instead of 2km/s for the sensitivity. We can then resolve the CO7-6 line (line width/resolution ~10) in order to compare the line profile with the CO(2-1) spectrum. The comparison of the line profiles of the low-J and the high-J transitions of CO will help us to determine the sub-structure of the clouds.
However, the [CI] line is fainter, so we use spectral averaging to lower the data rate and set the spectral resolution to 0.7km/s. Thus the line is partially resolved. We will smooth the spectrum to 2km/s when necessary to reach the minimum sensitivity to detect the line in the most diffuse regions, but we can also use the full resolution spectrum in the bright clumps to probe the structure.
We set the continuum measurements around 790.5 and 795GHz, where no strong lines will be detected, and where the atmospheric transmission is good.
References: Indebetouw et al. 2013, ApJ, 774, 73

We ask for an angular resolution of 0.5"x0.5" (~0.1 pc). This is approximately the size of the molecular gas/PDR transition gas that we expect for a half-solar metallicity gas exposed to an intense radiation field. This is supported by high-resolution studies of the Orion bar (Shimajiri et al. 2013, van der Werf et al. 1996).
We choose to focus on the individual clumps, with a maximum size of 1.2pc (Idebetouw et al., 20913). This is the reason why we need to recover the spatial scales up to 5".
References: Indebetouw et al. 2013, ApJ, 774, 73 Shimajiri et al. 2013, ApJL, 774, 20 van der Werf et al. 1996, ApJ, 313, 633

We estimate the sensitivity based on the intensity measured with Herschel/SPIRE/FTS for [CI] 370 microns and CO (J=7-6). Cycle 0 line widths for this region are ~3km/s (Indebetouw et al. 2013). From this, we deduce a minimum surface brightness of 160mJy in region B for [CI] 370 for a synthesized beam of 0.5"x0.5", if emission is uniform in the FTS beam. CO 7-6 emission is higher (890mJy), so the time estimation will be driven by [CI]. Since we do not need to spectrally resolve the lines for our study, we can post-process the data, smoothing them to 2km/s to reduce the observation time.
Moreover, from the cycle 0 observations, we expect the ISM to be very clumpy. Based on previous observations, the filling factor in the NANTEN2 data for [CI]370 and CO 7-6 is about 1/16 (Pineda et al., 2012). The resolution of NANTEN2 (26") is lower than the SPIRE/FTS beam (38"), so this gives a minimum value to the beam filling factor in the Herschel data. Thus, the emission in the clumps is expected to be enhanced by a factor of 16. To check this result, we compare the CO (2-1) value from the RADEX fit of the CO SLEDs at 43" resolution with the cycle 0 data at 2" resolution. We also find a factor of 8 enhancement. We will keep this value of 8 to be more conservative and to account for the fact that the clumps will be resolved, and estimate the peak line flux density per synthetised beam : 1.3Jy.
Then we have to take into account the fact that our 7 pointings are overlapping (Nyquist sampling). Thus the sensitivity in the 10pc x 10pc central region is increased by a factor of sqrt(2). For a signal to noise ratio of ~7 in the diffuse regions, we require a sensitivity of 1300/7*sqrt(2)= 263mJy. We confirm that the lines are in a good atmospheric transition window.
Since we do not require to spectrally resolve these lines for our study, we can post-process the data, smoothing them to 2km/s to reduce the observation time. The expected line width according to cycle 0 observation is ~3km/s.
References: Indebetouw et al. 2013, ApJ, 774, 73 Pineda et al. 2012, A&A, 544, 84

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO (2-1) 30Dor Region C
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Mapping of Region C in 30Dor.
In Region C, the CO(2-1) clumps are prominent and but here the G0 and n are lower (resp. 800 and 2400 cm^{-3}) and the fraction of CO-dark gas decreases.
We are observing 12CO(2-1) and 13CO(2-1) simultaneously in 2 different sidebands along with C18O(2-1) and the continuum around 233.5GHz.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We can observe simultaneoulsy 12CO(2-1), 13CO(2-1) and C18O(2-1). However, we have to choose a small spectral window (117 MHz) to be able to configure the LO1 for the simultaneous observation of 12CO and 13CO.
We apply an averaging factor of 4 to lower the data rate, and keep a resolution of ~0.15km/s since we expect the line width of the CO to be ~3km/s (cycle 0 observations). Then the lines in this band will be spectrally resolved, allowing us to probe the number of clouds on the line of sight.
We set the continuum measurement around 233.5GHz, where no strong lines will be detected, and where the atmospheric transmission is good.
References: Indebetouw et al. 2013, ApJ, 774, 73

We ask for an angular resolution of 0.5"x0.5" (~0.1 pc). This is approximately the size of the molecular gas/PDR transition gas that we expect for a half-solar metallicity gas exposed to an intense radiation field. This is supported by high-resolution studies of the Orion bar (Shimajiri et al. 2013, van der Werf et al. 1996).
We ask to recover the angular scales up to 14". This way we will observe the extended emission around the clumps, in the entire region covered by the band 10 mosaic.
References: Shimajiri et al. 2013, ApJL, 774, 20 van der Wef et al. 1996, ApJ, 313, 633

We estimate the sensitivity based on the Cycle 0 observations (Indebetouw et al. 2013). The faintest line we want to observe in this band is C18O, which dirves the time estimate. It is required because 13CO was found to be marginally thick in a few locations, especially in the dense clumps we are targetting. From Cycle 0 data, the brightest clumps have a C18O intensity of ~25mJy/beam. We then need to reach a sensitivity of 8mJy to detect C18O in the brightest clumps with a signal to noise ratio >3. If the emission is clumpier than expected, we will get a higher S/N due to our finer spatial resolution. This sensitivity allows us to detect the 13CO even in the diffuse zones. We confirm that the lines are in a good atmospheric transition window.
To reduce the integration time without jeopardizing the experiment, we can smooth to 0.3km/s (chosen bandwidth for the sensitivity calculation) and still resolve the lines in this band (line width/ bandwidth used for sensitivity = 10).
This is a single pointing. So we will reach the required sensitivity for the inner ~9" of the primary beam. This matches the size of the region that we fully sample in Band 10.
References: Indebetouw et al. 2013, ApJ, 774, 73

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CI, CO (7-6) 30Dor Region C
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Mapping of Region C of 30Dor.
In Region C, the CO(2-1) clumps are prominent and but here the G0 and n are lower (resp. 800 and 2400 cm^{-3}) and the fraction of CO-dark gas decreased by ~10%.
We are observing [CI] 370 microns and CO (7-6) simultaneously in in 2 different sidebands along with the continuum in the other 2 sidebands.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The expected line width is ~3km/s based on cycle 0 observations (Indebetouw et al. 2013). The CO7-6 line is 3.5 times brighter than [CI] in this region, so it will be detected with a lower S/N for a bandwidth of 0.3km/s instead of 2km/s for the sensitivity. We will have to smooth the spectra in the more diffuse zones, but in the other regions, we can resolve the CO7-6 line (line width/resolution ~10) in order to compare the line profile with the CO(2-1) spectrum. The comparison of the line profiles of the low-J and the high-J transitions of CO will help us to determine the sub-structure of the clouds.
However, the [CI] line is fainter, so we use spectral averaging to lower the data rate and set the spectral resolution to 0.7km/s. Thus the line is partially resolved. We will smooth the spectrum to 2km/s when necessary to reach the minimum sensitivity to detect the line in the most diffuse regions, but we can also use the full resolution spectrum in the bright clumps to probe the structure.
We set the continuum measurements around 790.5 and 795GHz, where no strong lines will be detected, and where the atmospheric transmission is good.
References: Indebetouw et al. 2013, ApJ, 774, 73

We ask for an angular resolution of 0.5"x0.5" (~0.1 pc). This is approximately the size of the molecular gas/PDR transition gas that we expect for a half-solar metallicity gas exposed to an intense radiation field. This is supported by high-resolution studies of the Orion bar (Shimajiri et al. 2013, van der Werf et al. 1996).
We choose to focus on the individual clumps, with a maximum size of 1.2pc (Idebetouw et al., 20913). This is the reason why we need to recover the spatial scales up to 5".
References: Indebetouw et al. 2013, ApJ, 774, 73 Shimajiri et al. 2013, ApJL, 774, 20 van der Werf et al. 1996, ApJ, 313, 633

We estimate the sensitivity based on the intensity measured with Herschel/SPIRE/FTS for [CI] 370 microns and CO (J=7-6). Cycle 0 line widths for this region are ~3km/s (Indebetouw et al. 2013). From this, we deduce a minimum surface brightness of 114mJy in region C for [CI] 370 for a synthesized beam of 0.5"x0.5", if emission is uniform in the FTS beam. CO 7-6 emission is higher (400mJy), so the time estimation will be driven by [CI]. Since we do not need to spectrally resolve the lines for our study, we can post-process the data, smoothing them to 2km/s to reduce the observation time.
Moreover, from the cycle 0 observations, we expect the ISM to be very clumpy. Based on previous observations, the filling factor in the NANTEN2 data for [CI]370 and CO 7-6 is about 1/16 acording to Pineda et al.(2012). The resolution of NANTEN2 (26") is lower than the SPIRE/FTS beam (38"), so this gives a minimum value to the beam filling factor in the Herschel data. Thus, the emission in the clumps is expected to be enhanced by a factor of 16. To check this result, we compare the CO (2-1) value from the RADEX fit of the CO SLEDs at 43" resolution with the cycle 0 data at 2" resolution. We also find a factor of 8 enhancement. We will keep this value of to be more conservative and to account for the fact that the clumps will be resolved, and estimate the peak line flux density per synthetised beam : 910mJy.
Then we have to take into account the fact that our 7 pointings are overlapping (Nyquist sampling). Thus the sensitivity in the 10pc x 10pc central region is increased by a factor of sqrt(2). For a signal to noise ratio of ~7 in the most diffuse regions, we require a sensitivity of 910mJy/7*sqrt(2) = 184mJy. We confirm that the lines are in a good atmospheric transition window.
Since we do not require to spectrally resolve these lines for our study, we can post-process the data, smoothing them to 2km/s to reduce the observation time. The expected line width according to cycle 0 observation is ~3km/s.
References: Indebetouw et al. 2013, ApJ, 774, 73 Pineda et al. 2012, A&A, 544, 84

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Our understanding of how gas is converted into stars quickly deteriorates as the metallicity of the interstellar medium decreases. While molecular gas is commonly accepted to be the main star-forming reservoir in normal galaxies like our Milky Way, the difficulty in tracing molecules in metal-poor galaxies complicates our ability to evaluate the star-formation efficiency or even the mere importance of molecular gas in the star-formation process. We propose a detailed modeling of the photodissociation front and molecular cloud in the half-solar metallicity environment of 30Dor in the Large Magellanic Cloud, in order to quantify the total molecular gas mass and the fraction of this gas that is not traced by the usual tracer CO (the CO-dark gas). Thanks to our previous modeling effort using Herschel tracers at 10pc resolution, we have identified a optimized combination of ALMA tracers that will provide the sufficient constraints to achieve our goals at 0.1pc resolution, i.e., a scale small enough to examine the transition between physical layers in molecular clouds.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.00471.S, 30 Doradus: Dense gas in the Nearest Super-Star Cluster, R. Indebetouw 2013.1.00346.S ; The first extragalactic, extreme, low-metallicity tests of the core mass function and molecular cloud structure ; R.Indebetouw
